document.docTitle: Anti-inflammatory and anti-proliferative activities of chemical constituents from fungus Biscogniauxia whalleyi SWUF13-085

paragraph.docTitle:
Anti-inflammatory and anti-proliferative activities of chemical constituents from fungus
Biscogniauxia whalleyi SWUF
13-085

document.paragraph:
Phongphan Jantaharn a
, Wiyada Mongkolthanaruk
b , Nuttika Suwannasai c , Thanaset Senawong d , Sarawut Tontapha e , Vittaya Amornkitbumrung e, f , Jaursup Boonmak g , Sujittra Youngme g , Sirirath McCloskey

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph: Graphostomataceae
Anti-proliferative activity Anti-inflammation
NO production
Bergamotene
α -pyrone
Guaiane
A B S T R A C T

The fungus
Biscogniauxia whalleyi SWUF
13-085 from the Graphostomataceae family was studied for potential anti-inflammatory and anticancer agents. A diverse array of natural products was identified. Six of which were undescribed compounds, including xylariterpenoids L-N, (1 R ,2 S ,6 R ,7 S )-1,2-dihydroxy- α -bisabolol, 6-[(1 R )-1- hydroxy-1-methyl-2-propenyl]-4-methoxy-3-methyl-2 H -pyran-2-one and (1 R *,4 S *,5 S *,7 S *,10 R *)-guaia-11 (12)- en-7,10-diol. Several of the isolated compounds such as bergamotene, guaiane and phthalide derivatives showed activity in both the inhibition of nitric oxide (NO) production in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-stimulated RAW264.7 macrophage cells with IC 50 values in the range of 2.48–10.82 μ g/mL and anti-proliferation against HeLa cells with IC 50 values in the range of 8.64–31.16 μ g/mL. While compounds such as cerebrosides A and C only exhibited inhibitory effects on NO production with IC 50 values in the range of 4.45–10.28 μ g/mL.

Fungi is one of the most significant sources for the discovery of potential drug candidates with research into their metabolites and compounds having produced a large number of well documented reports ( Cragg and Pezzuto, 2016 ; Newman and Cragg, 2020 ; Rayan et al., 2017 ). The
Biscogniauxia
genus previously belonged to the wood-decaying fungi, the Xylariaceae family. It was resurrected to the Graphostomataceae family in 2017, which comprises five genera that are made up of more than 136 species ( Wendt et al., 2017 ). Unlike Xylarials, for which there has been numerous reports on their bioactive compounds ( Becker and Stadler, 2021 ), there has only been a small number from this genus e.g. sesquiterpenoid analogues from Graphostoma sp. that were found to have potent anti-inflammatory properties ( Niu et al., 2017 , 2018 ).
* Corresponding author.
E-mail address: sirsod@kku.ac.th (S. McCloskey).

caption.paragraph: Table 1 1 H NMR data of compounds 1, 2, 3, 6, 7 and 13 (400 MHz, in CDCl, δ in ppm, J 3 in Hz).

subSection.paragraph:
The chemical constituents of
Biscogniauxia whalleyi (Graphostomataceae)
strain SWUF13-085 were isolated by chromatographic techniques, which resulted in the isolation of thirty-five compounds. The structure elucidation by the analysis of IR, NMR, MS, ECD and X-ray data revealed several classes of natural products e.g., bergamotene, α -pyrone, guaiane, dipeptide, steroid, and cerebroside derivatives, six of which were undescribed. The isolated compounds were evaluated for anti-inflammatory activity in terms of the inhibitory effect on NO production in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-stimulated RAW264.7 cells and anti-proliferation against cervical cancer cells (HeLa), colon cancer cells (HT29 and HCT116), breast cancer cells (MCF-7) and normal Vero cells. Herein, we have described the isolation, structure elucidation and the results of an anti-inflammatory and anti-proliferative activity evaluation.

The separation of crude extracts from the culture of
B. whalleyi SWUF
13-085 fungus yielded thirty-five compounds (1–35). The analysis of multiple data from IR, NMR, MS, ECD and X-ray crystallographic techniques and a comparison of those data with literature revealed a variety of natural products.

Compound 1 was obtained as a yellow viscous oil and the molecular formula C 15 H 22 O 2 was assigned by the positive ion peak in HRESIMS at m/z 257.1519 [M+Na] + (calc. for C 15 H 22 O 2 Na, 257.1517). The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) displayed proton signals of one olefinic methine at δ H 5.11 (t, J = 6.8, H-10), three methines at δ H 3.16 (s, H-4), 2.50 (br t, J = 5.9, H-6) and 2.39 (t, J = 5.9, H-2), three methylenes at δ H 2.06 (d, J = 10.5, H-1a) and 2.24 (dt, J = 10.5, 5.9, H-1b), 1.97 (m, H-9), and 1.76 (dd, J = 10.3, 6.9, H-8), and four methyls at δ H 1.68 (s, H-12), 1.60 (s, H-13), 1.49 (s, H-15) and 1.00 (s, H-14). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) showed a carbonyl ketone signal at δ C 206.1 (C-5) that corresponded with the strong absorption band of a carbonyl ketone at 1711 cm
1 in
the IR spectrum, and two olefinic signals at δ C 132.1 (C-11) and 123.7 (C-10). The COSY correlations of H-1 to H-2 and H- 6 in association with the key HMBC correlations of H-1 to C-2, C-3, C-5, C-6 and C-7, CH 3 -14 to C-2, C-6, C-7 and C-8, and CH 3 -15 to C-2, C-3 and C-4 suggested the presence of a bicyclo [3.1.1]heptane ring ( Fig. 2 ), a core structure of the bergamotene-type sesquiterpenoid ( Li et al., 2019 ; Niu et al., 2017 ; Wu et al., 2014b ). This was supported by the multiplicity patterns of the bridge-ring protons, i.e. H-1, H-2 and H-6 ( Fig. 3 ). The two bridgehead methine protons H-2 and H-6 that appeared as a triplet revealed the 3 J H2-H1b , 3 J H6-H1b and 4 J H2-H6 correlations with coupling constants of 5.9 Hz ( Wu et al., 2014b ), which contributed to the doublet of triplet of H-1b ( 3 J H1b-H2 = 5.9 Hz, 3 J H1b-H6 = 5.9 Hz and 2 J H1b-H1a = 10.5 Hz). However, the H-1a appeared as a doublet due to its coupling only with H-1b ( 2 J H1a-H1b = 10.5 Hz). A possible explanation for this could be that the dihedral angle of H-1a to the adjacent protons H-2 and H-6 ( 3 J ≈ 0 Hz) is around 90 ◦ thus there is no coupling among them. Signals from two high-field oxygenated carbons appeared at δ C 59.8 (C-3) and 59.2 (C-4) and the HMBC correlation of CH 3 -15 to C-2, C-3 and C-4 that corresponds with the absence of an OH-stretching absorption band in the IR spectrum. This revealed a 3,4-epoxide ring which is different from the typical bergamotene-core structure. The 4-methylpent-3-en-1-yl moiety was deduced by the COSY correlation of H-9 to H-8 and H-10 and the HMBC correlations of CH 3 -12,13 to C-10 and C-11, H-8,9 to C-7 and CH 3 -14 to C-7 and C-8 that supported the connection at C-7 of the bicyclic ring. The key NOESY correlations ( Fig. 4 ) of H-1b to H-8, and CH 3 -14 to H-4 indicated an exo -face pentenyl-substituted chain on the tricyclic ring, suggesting the relative configuration of 2 R *, 3 R *, 4 R *, 6 S * and 7 S *. The comparison of experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 5 ), showing Cotton effects at 208 (Δ ε = +0.03), 216 (Δ ε = 0.03), 228 (Δ ε = +0.01) and 324 (Δ ε = +0.03) nm that were similar to the calculated spectrum for (2 R ,3 R ,4 R ,6 S ,7 S )-1, led to the assignment of the absolute configuration of 1. The structure of 1 was therefore depicted as shown in Fig. 1 and named as xylariterpenoid L ( Li et al., 2019 ).

tableNote.paragraph: a The mixture labeled as 2a and 2b.
b The overlapping signals of 2a and 2b.

subSection.paragraph:
The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 2–5 showed some degree of similarity to 1. Compound 2 was obtained as yellow viscous oil and the molecular formula C 15 H 24 O 4 was determined according to the positive ion peak in HRESIMS at m/z 291.1573 [M+Na] + (calc. for C 15 H 24 O 4 Na, 291.1572). The shifted proton signal at δ H 3.33 (br d, J = 10.0, H-10), which corresponded to the carbon signals at δ C 78.7 (C-10) and 73.2 (C-11), indicated the presence of a dihydroxy group instead of a double bond as in 1. This was supported by the absorption band of an OH-stretching at 3403 cm
1 in
the IR spectrum. The 13 C NMR data of 2 showed some splitting carbon signals such as at C-2, C-5, C-6, C-7 and C-14, which suggested the mixture of two diastereomers (2a and 2b). The diastereomeric ratio of 2a and 2b could not be assigned based on the overlapping of almost every 1 H NMR signal. Nevertheless, the ratio of 1:0.7 of 2a and 2b was estimated from the integration of splitting 13 C NMR signals ( Otte et al., 2014 ). The key NOESY correlation of H-4 to CH 3 -14, 15 confirmed the exo -face of the pentenyl group. The comparison of the ECD spectra with 1 ( Fig. 5 ) suggested a similar absolute configuration on the tricyclic ring as 2 R , 3 R , 4 R , 6 S and 7 S . However, because they were isolated as a mixture, the configuration of C-10 could not be determined in this work. On the basis of the above data, 2 was identified as 10, 11-dihydroxy xylariterpenoid L, named as xylariterpenoid M.

caption.paragraph: 13 C NMR data of compounds 1, 2a, 2b, 3, 6, 7 and 13 (100 MHz, in CDCl, δ in 3 ppm).

subSection.paragraph: Compound 3 was isolated as a colorless viscous oil. Its molecular formula was C 15 H 22 O, based on the positive ion peak at m/z 219.1743 [M+H] + (calc. for C 15 H 23 O, 219.1749) in HRESIMS. When compared to 1, the 1 H NMR data of 3 showed an additional olefinic proton signal at δ H 5.73 (s, H-4). This corresponded to the 13 C NMR signals at 170.0 (C-3) and 121.5 (C-4). The HMBC correlation of CH 3 -15 to C-2, C-3 and C-4 ( Fig. 2 ) suggested that there was a double bond on the bicyclo [3.1.1] heptane ring instead of an epoxide ring. The key NOESY correlations of H-1b to H-8 and CH 3 -14 to H-4 ( Fig. 4 ) suggested a pentenyl chain in the exo -face of the bridge ring and the experimental ECD spectrum of 3 showed a similar pattern to the calculated ECD spectrum of (2 S ,6 S ,7 S )-3 ( Fig. 6 ). According to the above data, 3 was an undescribed bergamotene, named as xylariterpenoid N. Compounds 4 and 5 were isolated as a mixture in this work. The NMR spectroscopic data suggested partially similar structures to that of 2 and 3. For example, the signals of an alkenyl group on the bicyclo [3.1.1]heptane ring and a 10,11-dihydroxy group on the pentenyl chain. An intensive comparison of the NMR and ECD data to those in literature revealed that they are known xylariterpenoids A (4) and B (5) ( Niu et al., 2017 ; Wu et al., 2014b ).

Compound 6 was a yellow viscous oil. The IR spectrum displayed the strong absorption band of an OH stretching at 3344 cm 1 and the weak absorption band of a C––C stretching at 1707 cm 1 . At first glance, the 1 H NMR data of 6 resembled 1 and 3, showing two olefinic signals at δ H 5.71 (m, H-4) and 5.14 (t, J = 6.6, H-10) and four methyl signals at δ H 1.82 (s, H-15), 1.69 (s, H-12), 1.62 (s, H-13) and 1.22 (s, H-14). The 13 C NMR data also displayed four olefinic signals at δ C 132.1 (C-11), 131.2 (C-3), 126.0 (C-4) and 123.9 (C-10). Two oxygenated methine signals at δ H 4.29 (br s, H-1) and 3.81 (s, H-2) corresponded to 13 C NMR signals at δ C 72.2 (C-2) and 70.8 (C-1). The COSY correlation of H-9 to H-8 and H-10 in association with the HMBC correlations of CH 3 -12,13 to C-10 and C-11, and CH 3 -14 to C-6, C-7 and C-8 indicated a 2-hydroxy-6- methylhept-5-en-2-yl chain. The COSY correlations from H-1 to H-6 and the key HMBC correlations of CH 3 -15 to C-2, C-3 and C-4, H-1 to C-2, C-3, C-5, C-6 and C-7, H-2 to C-1, C-3, C-4, C-6 and C-15, H-4 to C-2, C-6 and C-15, and H-5 to C-3, C-4 and C-6 confirmed the 3-methylcyclohex-3-ene moiety. This data revealed that 6 was a bisabolol derivative with a substituted 1,2-dihydroxy group. Bisabolol is a precursor that goes through a C2–C7 ring closure to form the bergamotene ( Li et al., 2019 ). The key NOESY correlation of H-1 to H-2 and H-6 ( Fig. 4 ), and the broad singlets of H-1 and H-2 ( 3 J H1-H2 ≈ 3 J H1-H6 ≈ 0 Hz), corresponding to the cis form of the dihydroxy group ( Ardashov et al., 2011 ), led to the assignment of the relative configuration of 6 as 1 S *, 2 R * and 6 S *. This was supported by a comparison of the multiplicity patterns of H-1 (br s), H-2 (s) and H-6 (m) with four known synthetic compounds with similar core structures ( Ardashov et al., 2011 ; Kim et al., 2011 ). It resembled (1 S ,2 R ,6 R )- 3-methyl-6-(prop-1-en-2-yl)cyclohex-3-ene-1, 2-diol (see Fig. S 46 in SI). The absolute configuration was indicated by comparing experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 7 ). The spectrum showed Cotton effects at 210 (Δ ε = +0.35) and 223 (Δ ε = +0.15) nm, which were similar to the calculated spectrum of (1 R ,2 S ,6 R , 7 S )-6. Based on the above data and the positive ion peak at m/z 277.1784 [M+Na] + in HRESIMS accounting for the molecular formula C 15 H 22 O (calc. for C 15 H 26 O 3 Na, 277.1784), compound 6 was determined as (1 R ,2 S ,6 R )-6-(( S )-2-hydroxy-6-methylhept-5-en-2-yl)-3-met hylcyclohex-3-ene-1,2-diol, named (1 R ,2 S ,6 R ,7 S )-1,2-dihydroxy- α -bisa bolol.

Compound 7 was identified as α -pyrone derivative, named as 6- [(1 R )-1-hydroxy-1-methyl-2-propenyl]-4-methoxy-3-methyl-2 H -pyran-2-one. The molecular formula C 11 H 14 O 4 was deduced from the HRESIMS ion peak at m/z 233.0791 [M+Na] + (calc. for C 11 H 14 O 4 Na, 233.0790). The IR spectrum showed the broad absorption band of an OH stretching at 3393 cm 1 and the strong absorption band of an α,β- unsaturated carbonyl group of the α -pyrone ring at 1677 cm 1 ( Andolfi et al., 2015 ). The 4-methoxy-3-methyl-2 H -pyran-2-one-6-yl ring was deduced from the 1 H NMR signals of olefinic at δ H 6.46 (s, H-5), methoxy at δ H 3.91 (s, H-12) and methyl at δ H 1.63 (s, H-7), together with the 13 C NMR signals of carbonyl lactone at δ C 165.9 (C-2) and olefinic carbons at δ C 166.0 (C-4), 165.1 (C-6), 101.6 (C-3) and 91.7 (C-5). This was supported by HMBC correlations of CH 3 -7 to C-2, C-3 and C-4, H-5 to C-4 and C-6, and CH 3 O-12 to C-4. The 1 H NMR data also exhibited a set of olefinic proton signals at δ H 6.15 (dd, J = 17.3, 10.7, H-9), 5.40 (d, J = 17.3, H-10) and 5.24 (d, J = 10.7, H-10), corresponding to 13 C NMR signals at δ C 140.5 (C-9) and 114.7 (C-10). An oxygenated carbon was observed at δ C 73.7 (C-8). The COSY correlation of H-9 to H-10 and the HMBC correlations of H-10 to C-8 and C-9, and H-11 to C-6, C-8 and C-9 revealed the presence of a 2-hydroxybut-3-en-2-yl chain, substituted at C-6 of the α -pyrone ring. When compared to compounds from literature, 7 closely resembled synthesized 6-[(1 S )-1-hydroxy-1-methyl-2-propenyl]-4-meth oxy-3,5-dimethyl-2 H -pyran-2-one, except for the lack of a methyl group at C-5 ( Hatayama et al., 1993 ). The 8 R was assigned based on the [α] D 24.7 -99.0 ( c 0.60, CHCl 3 ), in contrast to the reported S configuration ([α] D +120.0, c 1.01 CHCl 3 ). The α -pyrone derivatives 8–12 were recognized immediately from their NMR spectra and the data were compared to those in literature. The results showed that they were the known phomopyrone A (8) ( Cai et al., 2017 ), gulypyrone B (9) ( Gong et al., 2015 ), 6-(1 ′ ,2 ′ -dimethyloxiran-1 ′ -yl)-4-methoxy-3-methyl-2 H -pyr an-2-one (10) ( Lu et al., 2009 ), nectriapyrone (11) ( Gong et al., 2015 ) and vermopyrone (12) ( Geiseler and Podlech, 2012 ).

Nine guaiane-type sesquiterpenes (13–21) were promptly recognized from the NMR spectroscopic patterns as they have been frequently found throughout this Graphostomataceae fungi family ( Amand et al., 2012 ; Niu et al., 2018 ). There was one undescribed derivative (13) along with eight known compounds, including patchouliguaiol A (14) ( Zhou et al., 2018 ), pogostol (15) ( Barra et al., 2014 ), xyralanone (16) ( Amand et al., 2012 ), xylaranol A (17) ( Li et al., 2010 ), epi -guaidiol A (18) ( Xu et al., 2009 ), (1 R ,4 S ,5 S ,7 R ,10 R ,11 S ) -guaiane-10,11,12-triol (19) ( Wu et al., 2014a ), (1 R ,4 S ,5 S ,7 R ,10 R ,11 R )-guaiane-10,11,12-triol (20) ( Wu et al., 2014a ) and graphostromane E (21) ( Niu et al., 2018 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Chemical structures of compounds 1–35; the undescribed bergamotenes, α -pyrone, and guaiane in blue, red and green, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph: The molecular formula C 15 H 26 O 2 of the colorless needle crystals of 13 was deduced from the positive ion peak in HRESIMS at m/z 261.1823 [M+Na] + (calc. for C 15 H 26 O 2 Na, 261.1830). The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed characteristic signals of a germinal alkene at δ H 5.03 and 4.69 (1H each, s, H-12) that corresponded to 13 C NMR signals at δ C 153.3 (C-11) and 107.2 (C-12). Three methyl signals were observed at δ H 1.77 (s, H-13), 1.17 (s, H-14) and 0.90 (d, J = 6.9, H-15). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) revealed two additional signals of an oxygenated-quaternary carbon at δ C 75.7 (C-7) and 74.1 (C-10). The HMBC correlations of H-12 to C-7 and C-13, and CH 3 -13 to C-7, C-11 and C-12 suggested a prop-1-en-2-yl fragment, substituted at the oxygenated C-7. The presence of a bicyclo [5.3.0]decane ring of a guaiane skeleton was demonstrated through the COSY correlations of H-3 to H-2 and H-4, H-5 to H-1 and H-6, and H-8 to H- 9 in association with HMBC correlations of H-1 to C-2 and C-10, H-6 to C-1, C-4, C-5, C-7 and C-8, CH 3 -14 to C-1, C-9 and C-10, and CH 3 -15 to C-3, C-4 and C-5. An intensive comparison of NMR data to those in literature showed that 13 was close to the known pogostol (15), apart from the presence of an additional hydroxy group at C- 7 in 13. The relative configuration of 1 R *, 4 S *, 5 S *, 7 S * and 10 R * was confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis (Mo Kα, see Supplementary data) ( Fig. 8 ). Therefore, 13 was assigned as 7-hydroxyprogostol, named (1 R *,4 S *,5 S *,7 S *,10 R *)-guaia-11 (12)-en-7,10-diol.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. COSY and key HMBC correlations of compounds 1, 2, 3, 6, 7 and 13.
Fig. 3. Key 1 H NMR region of the bergamotene’ s bicyclic ring analogues (1 and 3) demonstrating the multiplicity and coupling constants (J) of the bridgering protons.

subSection.paragraph: The intensive comparison of NMR data, specific optical rotation values, and MS data to those in literature showed that the other isolated compounds were 5-methylmellein (22) ( Okuno et al., 2014 ), 7-hydroxy-5-methoxy-4,6-dimethylphthalide (23) ( Jia et al., 2015 ), p -tyrosol (24) ( Park et al., 2011 ), and 5-hydroxy-2-prenylhydroquinone (25) ( Chien et al., 2012 ), four cyclic dipeptides (diketopiperazine); cyclo ( ʟ -Pro- ʟ -Val) (26) ( Campbell et al., 2009 ), cyclo ( ʟ -Pro-Gly) (27), cyclo ( ʟ -Pro- ʟ -Leu) (28) ( Yan et al., 2004 ) and cyclo ( ʟ -Pro- ʟ -Phe) (29) ( Furtadoa et al., 2005 ), and four steroids; ergone (30) ( Lee et al., 2005 ), ergosterol (31) ( Ragasa et al., 2018 ), ergosterol peroxide (32) ( Krzyczkowski et al., 2009 ) and cerevisterol (33) ( Ragasa et al., 2018 ). It is worth mentioning that a mixture of 34 and 35 was determined based on the HRESIMS displaying two major peaks at m/z 748.5397 (96.3) and 776.5675 (100) even though the 1 H and 13 C NMR data suggested the existence of one cerebroside derivative. These ion peaks corresponded to [M+Na] + of cerebroside A (calc. for C 41 H 75 NO 9 Na, 748.5340) and cerebroside C (calc. for C 43 H 79 NO 9 Na 776.5653) ( Koga et al., 1998 ). To support the assumption, methanolysis of the mixture was performed to assign the C-2 ʹ configuration and the lengths of the fatty acid fragments (see Supplementary data). The HRESIMS results of the metanolysed products displayed two main ion peaks [M+Na] + at m/z 327.0076 (89.7) and 335.2567 (100), which belonged to the sodium adduct ion of methyl 2-hydroxyhexadec-3-enoate (calc. for C 17 H 32 O 3 Na, 327.2249, the fatty acid fragment of cerebroside A) and methyl 2-hydroxyoctadec-3-enoate (calc. for C 19 H 36 O 3 Na, 335.2562, the fatty acid fragment of cerebroside C). Moreover, the specific optical rotation of the metanolysed products was [α] D 26.2 -3.0 ( c 0.60 CHCl 3 ), which corresponds to the 2 R configuration found in literature ([α] D 27 -5.1, CHCl 3 ) ( Shu et al., 2004 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Key NOESY correlations of compounds 1, 3, 6 and 13.
Fig. 5. Experimental ECD spectra of compounds 1 and 2 in CHCl 3 compared with calculated spectra of (2 R ,3 R ,4 R ,6 S ,7 S )-1 and (2 S ,3 S ,4 S ,6 R ,7 R )-1.
Fig. 6. Experimental ECD spectra of compound 3 and the mixture of 4 and 5 in MeOH compared with calculated spectra of (2 S ,6 S ,7 S )-3 and (2 R ,6 R ,7 R )-3.

subSection.paragraph: The NO production inhibition and anti-proliferative activity against HeLa, HT116, HT29, and MCF-7 cancer cells, and normal Vero cell lines were evaluated ( Table 3 ). The results showed that compounds 1, 3, 6, 15–17, 23 and a mixture of 34 and 35 exhibited a considerable inhibitory effect on NO production in the range of 2.48 ± 0.23 to 10.82 ± 1.3 μ g/mL. In addition, 1, 15, 17 and 23 were among the most toxic compounds against HeLa cells with an IC 50 range between 8.64 ± 1.22 and 31.16 ± 4.12 μ g/mL, while some of the compounds showed a broad spectrum of toxicity towards all cancer cells.

Thirty-five compounds were determined from fungus
B. whalleyi SWUF
13-085. They were structurally categorized into bergamotenes (1–6), α -pyrones (7–12), guaianoids (13–21), mullein (22), phthalide (23), phenolics (24–25), cyclic dipeptides (26–29), steroids (30–33) and cerebrosides (34 and 35). Among them, there were six undescribed compounds including xylariterpenoid L (1), xylariterpenoid M (2), xylariterpenoid N (3), (1 R ,2 S ,6 R ,7 S )-1,2-dihydroxy-α- bisabolol (6), 6- [(1 R )-1-hydroxy-1-methyl-2-propenyl]-4-methoxy-3-methyl-2 H -pyran-2-one (7) and (1 R *,4 S *,5 S *,7 S *,10 R *)-guaia-11 (12)-en-7,10-diol (13). The evaluation of the inhibition of NO production and anti-proliferative activity revealed that the isolated compounds from this fungus such as 16 and 23 were potential anti-inflammatory agents for a number of known diseases. Compound 23 was most effective in decreasing NO levels and it was specifically toxic against HeLa cells, making it a possible candidate that could be developed specifically for this type of cancer. Some of the compounds e.g. 1, 15, 17 and 23 exhibited both inhibition of NO production and anti-proliferative activity, which could be used to develop broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory and anti-cancer drugs. These results led to the conclusion that the fungus
Biscogniauxia
is a potential source of anti-inflammatory, chemopreventive and chemotherapeutic agents that should be further explored in terms of increasing the production of active compounds and molecular level studies.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 7. Experimental ECD spectrum of compound 6 in CHCl 3 compared with calculated spectra of (1R,2S,6R, 7R)-6, (1S,2R,6S, 7S)-6, (1R,2S,6R, 7S)-6 and (1S,2R,6S, 7R)-6.

subSection.paragraph:
Melting points were measured using a Sanyo/Gallenkamp MPD350. BM3.5 melting point apparatus. A JASCO DIP-1000 digital polarimeter was used to record optical rotation values. ECD and UV spectra were obtained from a JASCO J-810 circular dichroism spectropolarimeter. IR spectra were determined by a Bruker TENSOR27 FT-IR spectrometer. NMR spectra were recorded on Varian Mercury Plus 400 and Bruker 400 NMR spectrometers (400 MHz). High-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectra (HRESIMS) were measured on a micrOTOF Bruker mass spectrometer. The X-ray crystal data was collected on a Bruker D8 Quest PHOTON100 CMOS diffractometer with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073). For chromatographic separation, silica gel 60 ( 0.063 –0.200 mm and
0.040 –0.063 mm
, Merck, Germany ) were used for column chromatography (CC) and flash column chromatography (FCC). Sephadex LH-20 (Sigma-Aldrich, United States ) was used as the stationary phase for gel filtration chromatography. Preparative thin-layer chromatography (PLC) was performed using silica gel PF254 (Merck, Germany ) as the stationary phase.

The fungal stromata were collected in
August 2009
from corticated wood at Phu Khieo Wildlife Sanctuary in Chaiyaphum Province , Thailand (
16 ◦ 22 ʹ 48.0 ʺ N
101 ◦ 34 ʹ 16.0 ʺ E
). The fungal strain was identified by the morphological characteristics and molecular data (see Supplementary data). The nucleotide sequence analysis of 5 loci, ITS ( MW403821 ), LSU ( MZ452416 ), α- actin ( MZ466385 ), β- tubulin ( MZ466386 ), rpb2 ( MZ466387 ) confirmed that it is a new species and was named as
Biscogniauxia whalleyi SWUF
13-085. The specimen has been deposited in GenBank (accession number MW403821 ) and MycroBank (accession number MB840293 ). It is maintained at the Srinakharinwirot University Fungal Herbarium (SWUF) with the associated number of SWUF13-085
.

The fungal stroma was cultivated on potato dextrose agar (PDA) for 45 days. The pure cultures were then cut into small pieces and inoculated into yeast-malt extract (YM) liquid medium (yeast extract ( 3 g /L), malt extract ( 3 g /L), peptone ( 5 g /L), and dextrose ( 10 g /L)) and kept at room temperature for 45 days. Next, the culture solution (71 L in total) was filtered to obtain the mycelium and the broth. The broth was repeatedly extracted 3 times by EtOAc and solvent was removed to yield crude EtOAc extract ( 8.61 g ). The dried mycelium ( 124.14 g ) was ground into a powder and extracted by hexane, EtOAc, and MeOH (1200 mL × 3 for each with reused solvent) to give crude hexane ( 1.87 g , 1.51%), EtOAc ( 2.51 g , 2.02%) and MeOH ( 21.92 g , wet weight) extracts.

The separation procedures of the undescribed compounds (1–3, 6–7, and 13) are explained herein (for known compounds, see Supplementary data). The broth’ s EtOAc extract was fractionated on CC, eluted with a gradient system of hexane-EtOAc (stepwise from 100:0 to 0:100 v/v) and then EtOAc-MeOH (stepwise from 100:0 to 0:100 v/v) to yield 5 fractions (BE 1 -BE 5 ). Fraction BE 2 ( 384.1 mg ) was separated on FCC, eluted with hexane-EtOAc (9.5:0.5 v/v) to obtain 1 in BE 2.1 ( 26.4 mg ) along with 8 fractions (BE 2.2 -BE 2.9 ). The separation of BE 2.6 ( 92.1 mg ) was carried out on PLC, developed with hexane-acetone (4:1 v/v) to obtain BE 2.6.1 and BE 2.6.2 . Fraction BE 2.6.1 ( 20.5 mg ) was further purified by PLC, developed with hexane-CH 2 Cl 2 -EtOAc (5:4:1 v/v), which yielded 3 ( 8.8 mg ). Fraction BE 3 ( 1.1678 g ) was chromatographed on FCC, eluted with hexane-EtOAc (stepwise from 100:0 to 0:100 v/v) followed by EtOAc-MeOH (stepwise from 100:0 to 0:100 v/v) to afford 9 fractions (BE 3.1 -BE 3.9 ). Fraction BE 3.5 ( 363.2 mg ) was a mixture of white amorphous solid and yellow liquid. After filtration, the dried filtrate ( 176.1 mg ) was subjected to FCC, eluted with acetone-hexane (1.5:8.5 v/v) to afford 8 fractions (BE 3.5.1 -BE 3.5.8 ). Fraction BE 3.5.6 ( 16.9 mg ) appeared as a mixture of white amorphous solid and yellow liquid, from which the solid was then filtered out and recrystallized in MeOH– H 2 O (20:1 v/v) to yield 13 (9.0 mg). Fraction BE 3.7 ( 283.3 mg ) was fractionated on FCC, eluted with hexane-CH 2 Cl 2 -acetone (5:4:1 v/v) to obtain BE 3.7.1 -BE 3.7.17 . Compound 7 ( 5.5 mg ) was obtained from BE 3.7.7 ( 56.1 mg ), which was subjected to FCC, eluted with hexane-acetone (7:3 v/v) and then purified on Sephadex LH-20, eluted with MeOH. Fraction BE 3.7.12 (43.0 g) was fractionated on FCC, eluted with hexane-acetone (3:1 v/v) to obtain 6 ( 10.8 mg ). The fractionation of BE 4 ( 1.6349 g ) was carried out on FCC, eluted with hexane-EtOAc (stepwise from 100:0 to 0:100 v/v) and then EtOAc-MeOH (stepwise from 100:0 to 0:100 v/v) to afford BE 4.1 -BE 4.17 . Compound 2 ( 17.2 mg ) was obtained from BE 4.13.6 ( 88.8 mg ) when purified on Sephadex LH-20, eluted with MeOH.

caption.paragraph: Anti-proliferation and inhibitory effects on NO production of the isolated compounds.

tableNote.paragraph: a IC values referred to the concentration that cause 50% inhibition of NO production in LPS-induced RAW246.7 macrophage cells.
50 b IC values referred to the concentration that exhibited 50% of cell viability at 72 h, reported as mean ± SD ( μ g/mL).
50 c Positive control for anti-proliferative activity.
d Positive control for inhibitory effect on NO production.

document.paragraph: Colorless viscous oil; [α] 26.2 -112.8 ( c 0.85, EtOAc); UV (CHCl) D 3 λ max (log ε ) 261 (2.10) nm; ECD (CHCl 3 ) λ (Δ ε ) 346 (0.28), 222 (+0.05), 210 (+0.14) nm; IR ν max 2964, 2931, 1678, 1616, 1436, 1377 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 219.1743 [M+H] + (calc. for C H O, 219.1749). 15 23

subSection.paragraph: Yellow viscous oil, [α] D 26.2 -37.4 ( c 0.65, EtOAc); UV (CHCl 3 ) λ max (log ε ) 217 (2.57) nm; ECD (CHCl 3 ) λ (Δ ε ) 210 (+0.35), 223 (+0.15) nm; IR ν max 3344, 2967, 2917, 1707, 1441, 1376, 1015, 909, 828 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 277.1784 [M+Na] + (calc. for C 15 H 26 O 3 Na, 277.1784).

4.3.5. 6-[(1R)-1-Hydroxy-1-methyl-2-propenyl]-4-methoxy-3-methyl-2 H-pyran-
2-one (7)

Colorless needle crystals; m. p. 109.0–111.0 ◦ C; [α] D 26.3 -68.9 ( c 0.60, EtOAc); UV (CHCl 3 ) λ max (log ε ) 257 (2.12) nm; ECD (CHCl 3 ) λ (Δ ε ) 204 (+0.12), 305 (0.07) nm; IR ν max 3292, 2950, 2871, 1642, 1452, 1373, 1064, 1050, 901 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 261.1823 [M+Na] + (calc. for C 15 H 26 O 2 Na, 261.1830).

Crystallographic data for 13: C 15 H 26 O 2 , M = 238.36, orthorhombic, a = 8.994 (4) Å, b = 16.191 (9) Å, c = 20.127 (11) Å, α = 90 ◦ , β = 90 ◦ , γ = 90 ◦ , V = 2931 (3) Å 3 , T = 298 (2) K, space group P 212121 , Z = 8, D calc = 1.080 g /cm 3 , F (000) = 1056.0, μ(Mo Kα) = 0.069 mm 1 , 77,615 reflections collected, 5173 independent reflections ( Rint = 0.5388). The goodness-of-fit on F 2 was 0.982. The final
R 1
index was 0.0763 (I ≥ 2σ (I)). The final
wR 2
index was 0.1044 (I ≥ 2σ (I)). The final
R 1
index was 0.2616 (all data) and final wR2 index was 0.1485 (all data).

HeLa, HT29, HCT116, MCF-7, Vero and RAW264.7 cells were cultured in RPMI-1640 medium, supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 μ g/mL streptomycin (Gibco-BRL). The cell culture was further incubated with an atmosphere of 95% air and 5% CO 2 at 37 ◦ C in a humidified incubator.

heading.emphasis: 4.7. Anti-proliferative activity against cancer cell lines

subSection.paragraph: The anti-proliferative activity against HeLa, HT29, HCT116, MCF-7 and Vero cells was carried out by MTT colorimetric assay, following a previously described protocol ( Khaopha et al., 2015 ). The IC 50 value was considered as the concentrations that exhibited 50% cell viability for 72 h. Cisplatin was used as a positive control.

The cytotoxicity of compounds against RAW 264.7 cells was evaluated by MTT method to avoid a false result for the inhibition of NO production. The 85% cell viability result of the RAW 264.7 cells compared to the control (treated with only DMSO) allowed the compound to be used for further experimentation. Then, the RAW264.7 cells (2 × 104 cells/well) were cultured on 96-well plates for 24 h and then treated with selected compounds for 2 h. Lipopolysaccharide (LPS, 1 μ g/ mL) was added to the culture media, which was then incubated for 24 h. The level of NO in the media was determined by measuring the accumulation of nitrite (NO 2 ˉ ), a stable product of NO, using Griess reagent. The supernatant was mixed with an equal volume of Griess reagent (0.1% N -(1-naphthyl)-ethylenediamine dihydrochloride and 1% sulfanilic acid in 5% phosphoric acid) in each well followed by incubation for 10 min; this was followed by the recording of UV absorbance at 550 nm . The concentration of nitrite was assessed by comparisons with a standard curve of sodium nitrite solution. The IC 50 value was defined as the concentration that expressed 50% inhibition of NO production. N G - Monomethyl-L-arginine (L-NMMA), a nitric oxide synthase (NOS) inhibitor, was used as a positive control.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112908.
